description:
Cherax quadricarinatus, commonly known as the redclaw crayfish or blue crayfish, is a freshwater decapod crustacean species that belongs to the family Parastacidae. It is native to northeastern Australia and parts of Papua New Guinea.

The Cherax quadricarinatus is a relatively large crayfish, with a maximum carapace length of around 12 cm. It has a distinctive blue or green-blue coloration on its carapace and claws, with a reddish-orange color on the tips of its claws, which gives it the common name "redclaw". The species is characterized by four distinct longitudinal ridges or carinae on its carapace, which is the feature that gives it the scientific name "quadricarinatus".

Cherax quadricarinatus is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of aquatic plants, detritus, and small invertebrates. It is an important component of freshwater ecosystems and plays a role in nutrient cycling and decomposition processes. The species is also of commercial importance, as it is widely farmed and harvested for food in many regions.

Due to its hardiness, adaptability, and commercial value, Cherax quadricarinatus has been introduced to various parts of the world, including the United States, Mexico, and parts of Asia, where it is now considered an invasive species in some areas.
